name: Tina Turner
description:
'''Tina Turner''' (born '''Anna Mae Bullock'''; November 26, 1939 – May 24, 2023) was a singer, songwriter, actress, and author. Dubbed the "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Queen of Rock 'n' Roll]]", she [[Timeline of African-American firsts|broke both racial and gender barriers]] in [[rock music]] and became a dominant figure in [[popular culture]]. Known for her vocal prowess and stage presence, Turner is one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists of all time]], with estimated sales of over 100 million records worldwide.

Turner rose to prominence in the 1960s as the [[lead vocalist]] of the husband-wife duo [[Ike & Tina Turner]], known for their explosive live performances with [[the Ikettes]] and [[Kings of Rhythm]]. After years of marital abuse, she ended her personal and professional relationship with Ike Turner in the 1970s and embarked on a solo career. She made a [[Comeback (publicity)|comeback]] with her [[Music recording certification|multi-platinum]] fifth solo album ''[[Private Dancer]]'' (1984), whose single "[[What's Love Got to Do with It (song)|What's Love Got to Do with It]]" won the [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year]] and became her only number-one hit on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. Her worldwide chart success continued with the Top 10 singles "[[Better Be Good to Me]]", "[[Private Dancer (Tina Turner song)|Private Dancer]]", "[[We Don't Need Another Hero (Thunderdome)]]", "[[Typical Male]]", and "[[I Don't Wanna Fight]]". 

Turner's [[Break Every Rule World Tour]] became the [[List of highest-grossing concert tours#1980s|highest-grossing tour by a female artist of the 1980s]] and set a ''[[Guinness World Record]]'' for the then-[[List of most-attended concerts|largest paying audience in a concert]] (180,000). Her success as a live performer continued with the [[Wildest Dreams Tour]], the [[List of highest-grossing concert tours by women|first tour by a woman to earn $100 million]], and the [[Twenty Four Seven Tour]], the highest-grossing tour of 2000. In 2009, she retired from performing after completing the [[Tina!: 50th Anniversary Tour]]. As an actress, Turner appeared in the feature films ''[[Tommy (1975 film)|Tommy]]'' (1975), ''[[Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome]]'' (1985) and ''[[Last Action Hero]]'' (1993). Her life was dramatized in the biographical film ''[[What's Love Got to Do with It (1993 film)|What's Love Got to Do with It]]'' (1993), based on her autobiography ''[[I, Tina|I, Tina: My Life Story]]'' (1986). She was also the subject of the jukebox musical ''[[Tina (musical)|Tina]]'' (2018) and the documentary film ''[[Tina (film)|Tina]]'' (2021).

Turner received 12 [[Grammy Awards]], including a [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]] and three [[Grammy Hall of Fame]] inductions. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' ranked her among the [[Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Artists of All Time|greatest artists]] and [[Rolling Stone's 200 Greatest Singers of All Time|greatest singers]] of all time. She was the first black artist and first woman to appear on the [[List of people on the United States cover of Rolling Stone (1960s)|cover of ''Rolling Stone'']] and was the first female black artist to win an [[MTV Video Music Awards|MTV Award]]. Turner has a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]. She was inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] along with [[Ike Turner]] in 1991 and was later inducted as a solo artist in 2021. Turner was also a 2005 recipient of the [[Kennedy Center Honors]]. In 2013, Turner relinquished her U.S. citizenship and became a citizen of Switzerland, where she died in [[Küsnacht]] in 2023.
